citing_paper_authors: Hisami, Suzuki | Chris, Brockett | Gary, Kacmarcik
raw_text: Instead, we parse them into a default analysis, which can then be expanded and disambiguatcd at later stages of processing using a large semantic knowledge base (Richardson 1997, Richardson et al 1998)
clean_text: Instead, we parse them into a default analysis, which can then be expanded and disambiguatcd at later stages of processing using a large semantic knowledge base (Richardson 1997, Richardson et al 1998).

raw_text: Others have automatically extracted attribute relations from dictionary definitions (Richardson et al, 1998) ,structured on line sources such as Wikipedia info boxes, (Wu and Weld, 2007) and large-scale collections of high-quality tabular web data (Cafarella et al, 2008)
clean_text: Others have automatically extracted attribute relations from dictionary definitions (Richardson et al, 1998), structured online sources such as Wikipedia info boxes, (Wu and Weld, 2007) and large-scale collections of high-quality tabular web data (Cafarella et al, 2008).

citing_paper_authors: Chris, Brockett | Takako, Aikawa | Anthony, Aue | Arul, Menezes | Chris, Quirk | Hisami, Suzuki
raw_text: The Mindnet is a general-purpose database of semantic information (Richardson et al 1998) that has been re purposed as the primary repository of translation information for MT applications
clean_text: The Mindnet is a general-purpose database of semantic information (Richardson et al 1998) that has been repurposed as the primary repository of translation information for MT applications.

raw_text: MindNet (Richardson et al,1998) is both an extraction methodology and a lexical ontology different from a word net, since it was created automatically from a dictionary andits structure is based on such resources
clean_text: MindNet (Richardson et al, 1998) is both an extraction methodology and a lexical ontology different from a word net since it was created automatically from a dictionary and its structure is based on such resources.

citing_paper_authors: Lucy, Vanderwende | Gary, Kacmarcik | Hisami, Suzuki | Arul, Menezes
raw_text: Previous publications on MindNet (Suzuki et al, 2005, Richardson et al, 1998, Vanderwende 1995) have focused on the effort required to build a MindNet from the data contained in Japanese and English lexicons

clean_text: Such an approach was taken by the MindNet project (Richardson et al, 1998).

raw_text: One early example was MindNet (Richardson et al, 1998), which was based on collecting 24 semantic role relations from MRDs such as the American Heritage Dictionary
clean_text: One early example was MindNet (Richardson et al, 1998), which was based on collecting 24 semantic role relations from MRDs such as the American Heritage Dictionary.

raw_text: Richardson et al (1998) describes how MindNet began as a lexical knowledge base containing LF-like structures that were produced automatically from the definitions and example sentences in machine-readable dictionaries
clean_text: Richardson et al (1998) describes how MindNet began as a lexical knowledge base containing LF-like structures that were produced automatically from the definitions and example sentences in machine-readable dictionaries.

raw_text: Synonymy ,hypernymy or meronymy fall clearly in this latter category, and well known resources like WordNet (Miller, 1995), EuroWordNet (Vossen, 1998) or MindNet (Richardson et al, 1998) contain them
clean_text: Synonymy, hypernymy or meronymy fall clearly in this latter category, and well known resources like WordNet (Miller, 1995), EuroWordNet (Vossen, 1998) or MindNet (Richardson et al, 1998) contain them.
